column4: So, I just installed a fresh install of 9.10 on my laptop because the sound was a clusterfuck after upgrading from 9.04. I *still* cannot play sound from two sources at a time, however. Could this because mpd uses alsa directly? Do I need to make it use pulseaudio?
(E.g., I hear no sound from youtube videos at the same time I play music, need to stop playing music)
Also, can someone tell me what's going on with the sounds when tab-completing stuff in a terminal? It's not the beep, as it's muted
You're talking about the "bell"?
It could be that, yes
It's still a "bell", even if it's muted. Under some sessions it can flash the screen. You may want to set the bell-style to none in xinputrc. Or something. I always have to google that.
What's your sound card?
Some realtek(alc268), using hda intel drivers
Maybe there's a way to "dpkg-reconfigure" some alsa / pulseaudio stuff that will take advantage of the fact that you upgraded? I'm guessing.
I reinstalled completely
That answers that. :-/
Which is why I'm pretty baffled. I'm still getting strange 'sound takeovers'
Yeah, but not everything's been converted to use it yet. :-(
how do I know if I'm even using it?
Good question. I'm a recent convert from Gentoo, and, there, I used to just eliminate pulseaudio from my system entirely.
Yeah.. That's what I tried to do last time, before reisntalling completely
So, I don't think removing pulseaudio will be such a good idea.. I just tried playing sound through pulseaudio in VLC, and it's lagging to utter s**t.
What desktop environment do you run?
Fluxbox - think it might affect it?
Well, I was just going to say that, if you were running Gnome, I'd go for installing MORE gstreamer stuff, not taking stuff out.
But I'm not sure if Flux is as "plugged" into gstreamer as Gnome.
God this seems strange, all of it, heh..
I agree. I've been through many of these types of switchovers in Linux land over the years. It sucks if you get caught out.
I'll just ask on ubuntuforums or something - thanks for the help.
